title: How to Stucco a Ceiling

steps.headline: Remove all furniture from beneath the ceiling.
steps.description: Be sure all the walls are free of dust because stucco will not stick to dust. Cover all walls, and any furniture you cannot remove, with plastic sheeting. Secure the sheeting tightly with masking tape.

steps.headline: Mix the stucco in a large bucket.
steps.description: First put the dry mix in, then add water and stir. Follow the directions given with the mix.

steps.headline: Test the consistency of the wet stucco by shoveling some onto your trowel.
steps.description: If the stucco slides off when you tilt the trowel to an angle of 90 degrees, it is too wet and will drop off the ceiling when you apply it.

steps.headline: Load the sprayer with the wet stucco.
steps.description: Follow instructions given with the sprayer regarding how much to load. This will allow you not only to practice applying the stucco, but to test the consistency of your mix. If you are dissatisfied with how it looks, go back to Step 2 and add more dry mix or more water.

steps.headline: Test out the sprayer by spraying the wet stucco onto a large piece of cardboard.
steps.description: Get a feel for the speed and movement of the sprayer.

steps.headline: Place your ladder in a corner of the room.
steps.description: Put on your mask and safety glasses. Make sure that you can easily and safely get within range of the ceiling.

steps.headline: Begin spraying the ceiling with wet stucco in even, horizontal gestures.
steps.description: Do not go over the same area twice or the stucco will be too heavy and fall off in big chunks.

steps.headline: Examine your first application closely to ensure that it has the consistency and texture you want.
Move your ladder when you can no longer spray the ceiling easily.
steps.description: From your new position, start spraying again.

steps.headline: Continue to move the ladder around the room and apply stucco in even strips until the ceiling is completely covered.
Let the stucco sit for 8 hours until dry.

Cover all walls, and any furniture you cannot remove, with plastic sheeting. Secure the sheeting tightly with masking tape. Mix the stucco in a large bucket. First put the dry mix in, then add water and stir. Follow the directions given with the mix. Test the consistency of the wet stucco by shoveling some onto your trowel. If the stucco slides off when you tilt the trowel to an angle of 90 degrees, it is too wet and will drop off the ceiling when you apply it. Load the sprayer with the wet stucco. Follow instructions given with the sprayer regarding how much to load. This will allow you not only to practice applying the stucco, but to test the consistency of your mix. If you are dissatisfied with how it looks, go back to Step 2 and add more dry mix or more water. Test out the sprayer by spraying the wet stucco onto a large piece of cardboard. Get a feel for the speed and movement of the sprayer. Place your ladder in a corner of the room. Put on your mask and safety glasses. Make sure that you can easily and safely get within range of the ceiling. Begin spraying the ceiling with wet stucco in even, horizontal gestures. Do not go over the same area twice or the stucco will be too heavy and fall off in big chunks. Examine your first application closely to ensure that it has the consistency and texture you want.  Move your ladder when you can no longer spray the ceiling easily. From your new position, start spraying again. Continue to move the ladder around the room and apply stucco in even strips until the ceiling is completely covered.  Let the stucco sit for 8 hours until dry.  Remove the plastic sheeting.
